eu.trentorise.opendata.commons

Class Dict

  • java.lang.Object
    • eu.trentorise.opendata.commons.Dict
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Serializable

    @ParametersAreNonnullByDefault
@Immutable
public final class Dict
extends Object
implements Serializable
    Represents a dictionary of a string that may have translations in several languages. There can also be multiple strings for the same language, in this case the first one is the preferred. Never pass null objects to methods, use empty objects (such as empty String "", unknown Locale Locale.ROOT, etc...) instead.

    To create Dict instances use of(...) methods.

    Author:
    David Leoni
    See Also:
    Serialized Form

      • contains

        public boolean contains(String text)
        Checks if provided text is contained in any of the provided translations. Both text and translations to check are lowercased according to their locale.
        Parameters:
        text - the text to search for
        Returns:
        true if text is contained in any of the translations, false otherwise

      • nonEmptyString

        public String nonEmptyString(Locale locale)
        Returns the first non empty string in the given locale. If it can't find it, an empty string is returned.
        Parameters:
        locale - the locale of the desired tranlsation. If unknown, use Locale.ROOT.

      • anyString

        public LocalizedString anyString(Iterable<Locale> locales)
        Deprecated. use some(java.lang.Iterable) instead
        Tries its best to return a meaningful string in one of the provided languages.
        Returns:
        A string in the first available language from the list of provided locales. If no translation is available, in order, defaults to English and then whatever it can find in the list of translations. Empty strings are discarded. If no valid translation is available at all, returns LocalizedString.of().

      • some

        public LocalizedString some(Locale... locales)
        Tries its best to return a meaningful string in one of the provided languages. For more details, see anyString(java.util.Locale...) Superceeds anyString(java.util.Locale...).
        Since:
        1.1

      • some

        public LocalizedString some(Iterable<Locale> locales)
        Tries its best to return a meaningful string in one of the provided languages. Superceeds anyString(java.lang.Iterable).
        Returns:
        A string in the first available language from the list of provided locales. If no translation is available, in order, defaults to English and then whatever it can find in the list of translations. Empty strings are discarded. If no valid translation is available at all, returns LocalizedString.of().
        Since:
        1.1

      • with

        public Dict with(Locale locale,
        String... strings)
        Returns a new dictionary with provided array of strings with the same locale. Strings will be appended to existing ones for the same locale.
        Parameters:
        locale - the locale of the strings
        strings - the strings in the given locale

      • with

        public Dict with(String... strings)
        Returns a new dictionary with provided array of strings with the same locale unknown locale Locale.ROOT. Strings will be appended to existing ones with unknown locale.
        Parameters:
        strings - the strings in the given locale

        strings - the strings in the given locale

      • with

        public Dict with(Dict dict)
        Returns a new dictionary which is the result of merging this dictionary with the provided one. New locales and strings follow any existing locales and strings.
